has requested a rate hike from the Maryland Public Service
Commission. BG&E claims that it needs an additional $199
million of revenue in order to raise their rate of return to its

raise profits while people in Baltimore are suffering," commented
C/LEC spokeswoman Ann Feldman.

Young Democrats HearSpecial Interest Groups
BY DOREEN MORAN
The Young Democrats of
Maryland, in an attempt to
encourage involvement in political affairs, presented a public
hearing October 19 to hear
testimony from representatives
of special interest groups. They
were asked to contribute their
ideas so that the Young Democrats will have a better idea as to
what planks in their platform
need revision.
Each of the nine witnesses
was given a set time to issue his
or her statement, and then
received questions from. the
panel:
Brett Weiss, Charles
Kruzansky, Leonard Lucci, Greg
Pecararo, and Vincent De Marco.
Charlie King of Americans
for Democratic Action said
liberals are in the process of
reassessment, and thus should
steer their interests towards the
goals of education for all, and
the availability of financial aid
for those who cannot afford
higher education. He said "an
education process needs to take
place" in regard to Reaganomics
and seemed worried about
"President Reagan's retrenchment on civil rights."
This was also the concern of
Laura Murphy of the American
Civil Liberties Union. Murphy
concentrated mostly on the
Voting Rights Act, which is up
for reassessment, and how this
reassessment was seen as a
"structural attack on amendments to the Constitution."

At the present, several mostly
southern states are covered by
the act. The Justice Department
reviews all laws passed within
these states to make sure they
are not discriminatory. Brett
Weiss, chairman of the hearing,
found it "ironic" that such a
substantial piece of legislation is
up for reassessment.
One key issue for the Young
Democrats seems to be the
recruitment of minorities into
the party. Charlie King suggested that blacks are disenchanted
with the party but offered
another problem in their recruitment: if you seek out minorities, you will seem paternalistic;
if you ignore them, you are
racist.
George Bunt of the NAACP

way to interest minorities in the
Democratic Party again is to
support programs that will appeal to them. Murphy agreed,
observing that the people do
not participate because they do
not believe the system works for
them.
Three other key issues were
discussed: nuclear power, the
Family Protection Act and abortion. On the latter subject, three
people testified: Professor Chris

Williams of the National Lawyers Guild, Joseph McPherson of
Maryland Right to Life, and
Steve Rivilus of Planned Parenthood of Maryland.
Williams concentrated on
the Family Protection Act currently being sponsored in Congress, which has sometimes been
called the "right-wing shopping
list."
The act's provisions
include "an all-out attack on
gay/lesbian citizens," and tax
incentives for households which
contain aged people. Such an
incentive is seen as a means of
keeping the family a unit.
Actually, according to Williams,
this would be a burden to the
family, keeping a family member
— most likely the woman — at
home to care for the aged one.
This, said Williams, is the intent
of the sponsors, who want to
deny women their rights, and is
"an effort to legalize government intrusion into areas of
private choice.., in the right-wing
conservative tradition."
Joseph McPherson presented a different perspective. He
sees the 1973 Supreme Court
ruling in favor of abortion as an

adding that it is "an exercise
in raw judicial power." By such
measures, he believes our government "loses its moral authority." McPherson then argued
that because society loses its
respect for itself, weapon production and economic stimulation occur. When questioned, he
explained that once a healthy

family life has been lost, material goods become more important; hence, the economy is
stimulated.
He offered no
evidence to back up his theory.
Steve Rivilus, Public Affairs
Director of Planned Parenthood,
followed McPherson. He told
the panel that the "Democrats
should regroup" to protect the
rights of the poor, minorities,
women, and aged. Strongly
opposed to any restriction of
reproductive freedom, Rivilus
said that since there is no right
